NOTES ON AIRPORT
Friday, Sept. 17, 1926.
At the request of the chamber o1 Commerce and suggested
by
of
the Supervisors attending the luncheon to Assistant Secretary
the Navy Warner, I met Mr.
Manner and the officers of the
Twelfth Naval Division at Harrison and Spear Streets at 2:30 o'clock.
We left soont 3:00 o'clock and visited the Sonth San Francisco site
and Millbrae site.
Did not visit the San Mateo site, as it was not
suitable for hydroplanes. Returned to San Francisco at 4:45 o'clock.
The Assistant Secretary expressed the opinion that the
site at South San Francisco was not admirably adapted for
planes, as the hydroplane would probably have
hydro-
to
to taxi at some three
miles berore it could start
of water is needed
hydroplanes, according
Depth
to the Assistant Secretary, in order to enable
boats to deliver supplies direct to the hy√¢roplanes.
We also visited the Millbrae site and the Assistant
Secretary said that it appeared to him that this was a much better
site.
Not being familiar with the direction of the winds at all
times he could not state whether it was ideal or not.
He also asked
concerning drainage on both sites and whether during the winter
season the land would be waterlogged.
He also made the statement
that if it were a question of securing a field not suitable for
hydroplanes but absolutely clear of fog, that he would select that
field rather than take a field suitable for hydroplanes that had
fog at times.
lir.

party; also Rear-Admiral Thomas Washington, Commandant of the District
